Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Hazards and Risks of Climate Change in the Pacific Northwest
Award.AbstractNarration:
The hazards and risks associated with climate change are a pressing concern in the Pacific Northwest. Assessing risks associated with climate-related hazards requires an interdisciplinary approach that explores the nature of the hazard itself; the economic, social, and political vulnerabilities of the communities in the region; and communication strategies that reach a diverse audience. The primary goal of this project is to introduce students to and engage them in interdisciplinary hazards research that is relevant to their lives and livelihoods, and to do so early in their college careers. The project will bring up to 10 students per year from community colleges, tribal colleges, and universities throughout the Pacific Northwest to Central Washington University to conduct research spanning multiple disciplines, including hydrology, atmospheric science, sociology, geography, geology, and documentary film-making. Students will also work together on a grand challenge project to survey their communities about their perceived risks to climate change, integrate their individual research projects, and develop resources for communicating about climate change risks back to their own communities. They will present the results of their work at a regional conference hosted at CWU.

An additional goal of this project is to develop a community around the idea of interdisciplinary climate hazards and risks research, one that can not only advance our understanding of these topics, but one that serves as a support network for transfer students, especially those from two-year colleges, to succeed in the four-year college environment. Many students at regional community colleges are from groups traditionally underrepresented in the STEM disciplines, and their communities are particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. This project will support ongoing interactions between students, faculty at their home institution, faculty and students at Central Washington University, and the surrounding communities, emphasizing the role of research in building resiliency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The hazards and risks associated with climate change are a pressing concern in the inland Pacific Northwest. A robust agricultural industry relies on a freshwater supply moderated by snowpack, which is melting our earlier; residents and forests are threatened by fires intensified by drought; wildfires and smoke are impacting public health and tourism. Assessing risks associated with these hazards requires an interdisciplinary approach that explores the nature of the hazard itself; the economic, social, and political vulnerabilities of the communities in the region; and communication strategies that reach diverse audiences. The REU Site: Hazards and Risks of Climate Change in the Pacific Northwest supported 32 students over four years in conducting mentored research with faculty at Central Washington University (CWU) in Ellensburg, WA, to contribute to our understanding of these concerns and to develop their skills in communicating the hazards and risks of climate change to their communities.

Research areas spanned several disciplines, and included topics such as Reconstructing changes in wildfire regimes in the Pacific Northwest through lake sediment core analysis, determining the impact of wildfires and smoke on tourism, assessing changes in melting rates of permanent snow fields in the Cascades, gathering perceptions of climate change impacts from farmers and ranchers in Central Washington, assessing the heat- and drought-tolerance of agriculturally-important crops, and determining the factors that influence stink bug migrations and their impacts on fruit orchards. Each cohort of students also engaged in a group challenge projects--developing and conducting a climate change risk perception survey, producing climate-related informational materials in advance of the midterm elections, and analyzing climate-related graphics in popular media--focused on effective means of communicating the complex, interdisciplinary nature of climate change science and impacts. They presented the results of their work at the Northwest Climate Conference, a regional conference that brings together scientists, practitioners, tribal members, government leaders, and community organizers to work towards a climate-resilient Northwest.

One quarter of the participants were community college students, and just under a half (15/32) were in their first two years of college--groups for whom significant research experiences are often not available. All students who participated in the program reported learning gains in their research abilities, and many have continued in climate-related research and jobs after their participation. Our survey and evaluation results suggest that the REU Site at CWU made significant progress toward its goal of developing the interdisciplinary problem solving skills and personal efficacy in the next generation of STEM workers who will face ongoing challenges in mitigating climate-related risks affecting the diverse communities in the Pacific Northwest.
